Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Czechoslovakia. Member of Kibbutz Maanit. Senior member of Absorption Department of Jewish Agency until 1956. Aliyah activities of Hakibbutz Haartzi; Hashomer Hatzair executive, 1945. Representative of Jewish Agency and later administrator of Athlit detention camp. Active in Central Housing Committee in Tel Aviv from 1949. Contacts with authorities in Cyprus responsible for immigrants en route at sea. Active absorption and dispersal of newcomers in settlements and transit camps, 1948. Difficulties in housing and employment and in absorption of socially problematic immigrants. Newcomers preferring to settle in urban centers. Policy of integrating different communities. Establishment of Amidar, 1949. Establishment of Kiryat Gat. Permanent housing partly financed by newcomers, 1953. Work villages, 1954 onwards.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Saqqez, Iran, 1922. Activities among newcomers, including representation in dealings with American Joint Jewish Distribution Committee (JDC) and Jewish Agency. Public activity in Iran, including Azarbaijan, before State of Israel established. Motives for aliyah. Conditions in Teheran transit camps. Activities of different public institutions on behalf of Persian Jews.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Bessarabia, Russia in 1915. Secretary of Histadrut in Kiryat Ata. Served in British Army, 1940. Active in Jewish Brigade committee at Diaspora Center as organizer of Beriha and hapala. Work at absorption department of Jewish Agency, 1946. Work with immigrants in Athlit and Kiryat Shmuel transitional camps. Dispersal of immigrants from detention camps in Cyprus and Israel to adopting families, 1947-1949. Manager of Haifa Amidar for 25 years. Development and maintenance of different settlements. Initial absorption procedures for newcomers.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Saqqez, Iran in 1929. Life in Azarbaijan. Reasons for aliyah of entire community. Different transitional camps for Iraqi and Iranian immigrants. Help from Jewish community in Teheran. Aliyah, 1950. Father provided statistical details of Azarbaijan Jews to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-15 באוקטובר 2019, המתעדים את חג הסהרנה, הנחוג בקרב יוצאי כורדיסטאן בגן סאקר בירושלים. הסהרנה היא חג טבע, הדומה למימונה של יהודי מרוקו, שיהודי כורדיסטן היו חוגגים בפסח. בישראל, כדי לא להתחרות במימונה, העבירו יוצאי כורדיסטן את החג לסוכות. ביום הראשון של חול המועד סוכות התקיימה הסהרנה בירושלים. נעשו הכנות רבות להשתתפות קהל רב, אבל כנראה בגלל מזג האוויר היו רק משתתפים מעטים. אחרי הצהריים היו במקום רק כמה משפחות שערכו פיקניק על הדשא וכמה צעירים שהתאמנו בצעדי ריקוד כורדי. לפנות ערב נערכה תהלוכה של הכנסת ספרי תורה. השתתפו בה כחמישים איש, לא כולם יוצאי כורדיסטן. רק אישה אחת באה בשמלה כורדית אמיתית. את התהלוכה הובילו שני נגני זוּרְנָה (מין אבוב) ושני מתופפים והוליכו בה שני ספרי תורה. כמה נשים הצמידו מטפחות-ראש לספרי התורה ורבים רקדו לקול המוסיקה. כשהגיעו לאוהל בית הכנסת גברו הריקודים ורבים הסתדרו בשורה ארוכה לריקוד של מין דבקה כורדית. לסיום הניחו את ספרי התורה על שולחן, רב נשא תפילה, הגברים התפללו מנחה ובזה הסתיים החלק הראשון של הטקס. בערב נערכו הופעות מעל במה שהוקמה במקום.

Contribution of Jewish Communal Activities in Latin America to the Establishment of the State of Israel, 1945-1949.

descriptions.value: Born Czechoslovakia, 1920. Aliyah before WWII. Served as Ambassador to Israel in several countries. Discusses: involvement in illegal immigration to Israel; representing Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Rio de Janeiro, 1960; posts in Africa, Latin America and in delegation to U.N.; arriving in Uruguay, 1975; Rodriguez Fabrequat; arranging Fabrequat's visits to Uruguay; trying to organize Fabrequat's funeral to meet his wishes; Uruguay's unique position on Israel; support for Israel in both major parties, Loborados and Blancos; Jews active in political campaign, especially Jacobo Hazan; Battle Blers; Payse Reyes; 'El Pais'; Juana de Jbarburu; support Moshe Tov mustered amongst personalities.

Thousands of West Bank settlers and their supporters squatted on hill tops and blocked major intersections in an attempt to block the peace process and the expected transfer of land and authority to the Palestinians.

descriptions.value: Hundreds were arrested and the leader group, which blocked the intersections in an illegal demonstration was fined $3000. Some politicians criticized the disruption of life inside Israel proper. The feared such disrupton may turn Israeli against them. However public opinion polls showed a small majority sympetized with the settlers. Photo shows women soldiers evacuating a settler from Givat Hadagan north of Efrat. Most settlers showed passive resistance. July 31, 1995.

Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Former mayor of Beer Sheva. Memories from 1947-1948, then engineer for Solel Boneh on the Southern Command in Israel, heading 300 workers. Only several secluded settlements in the Negev then with no water or defense. Organization of contact between Southern settlements and the army who took care of food supplies and protection. Camp settled in Nir-Am, until the front moved south and then settled in deserted houses in Beer-Sheva in 21.10.1948. This being the outset of the civilian foundation of the city. In 1949 when Golda Meir was Minister of Labor, resources were found for raw materials for building the city in the nearby dunes of Revivim. Connecting to water supplies from local wells and to electricity and telephone lines with minimum expenses and a lot of good will on part of the state authorities. 7,000 people in immigrant camp during snowy winter of 1950. Beginning of education in city conducted in schools from British mandate period. The Histadrut investing a fortune in Beer-Sheva out of a will to assist absorption of newcomers. Commending the establishment of the university in city which helps promote matters of culture and education. Claims that the government should take it to distribute the population and settle half of the forth million that will arrive to Israel between 1973-1983 in the Negev, with Beer Sheva as the central city in this district.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-27 באפריל 2019, המתעדים את טקס שריפת עגל הזהב בעין הוד. בשנות התשעים של המאה הקודמת התכנסה מועצת כפר האמנים עין הוד כדי להחליט כיצד יחגוג הכפר את הפסח בדרכו המיוחדת. נקבע שבכל שנה אמן אחר יכין עגל זהב שאותו ישרפו בטקס המוני שמח. "הרעיון הוא שאמן יעבוד על פסל, שאותו יעלו באש. כך ילמד האמן שהאגו שלו מוגבל ובן-חלוף" - כך אמרה לדנצ'ו ארנון נחמה, שבעלה ז"ל היה בין מייסדי הטקס. בשנת 2019 הוטל התפקיד על אלון ירקוני. הנושא - המאבק על אסדת הגז. לכן טרחו אלון ובני משפחתו והכינו עגל זהב שחציו לוויתן. בארבע אחרי הצהריים העמיסו את העגל, עטוף במעטה, אל כיכר הכפר.לקראת שש בערב היו כל תושבי הכפר ואורחים מכונסים בכיכר. אהרון הכהן עלתה למרפסת המזכירות וקראה בפאתוס את דבר היום, שעסק בנזקי אסדת הגז. כשסיימה, הסירו את הלוט מעל לפסל לקול תיפוף להקת מתופפים והקהל התחיל לרקוד מסביבו, כשבידי רבים בקבוקי משקה. לאחר זמן מה נשאו כמה גברים את הפסל ותהלוכה גדולה וצוהלת יצאה אל תצפית הכפר, ובראשה אהרון הכהן מחזיקה בחופן דולרים. ביציאה מהכפר הצטרפה לתהלוכה חבורת "בני ישראל", ילדים שהכינו ניסים עם ציורי סמלי 12 שבטי ישראל.כשהתהלוכה הגיעה לתצפית הניחו את העגל במרכז הרחבה. משה רבנו ירד מהר סיני וטיפס בסולם אל גג סככת התצפית, שם הניף את לוחות הברית וקרא את דבר שומרי איכות הסביבה. לאחר מכן הוא ירד אל העגל והצית אותו ואת הלוחות. כל אותו זמן העם רקד סביב העגל לקול התופים ונרגע רק כשמהעגל נותר רק אפר.

descriptions.value: מזרחי עלתה לישראל מבגדאד לחיפה בסוף 1937, עם בעלה ו-4 ילדיה בעזרת סרטיפיקט שהשיגה משפחת בעלה בישראל. 4 ילדים נוספים שילדה נפטרו בעיראק. מזרחי אינה יודעת באיזה תאריך נולדה. הייתה בת יחידה לאב עשיר שייצר צבעים, צבעי בדים והיה בעל כרמים בהם העסיק פועלים מוסלמים. הוא נפטר בילדותה, והיא גדלה במשפחת אחי האב בדהוק ונישאה לבנו. כשהאב היה בחיים, מימן את פעילותו של בית מדרש שבו למדה יחד עם כ- 50 בנים והייתה הבת היחידה שם. בית המדרש נסגר עם מותו. אמה עסקה בטוויה ובאריגה. הנישואין סוכמו בין הורי הצדדים והיה מקובל לשלם לכלה המיועדת 1000 לירות. בדהוק הנשים לא כיסו את פניהן בהיותן מחוץ לבית, לא כך בבגדאד, וכן היו קשרים טובים וביקורי שכנים הדדיים בין יהודים למוסלמים.

It was disclosed today by the Jewish Agency that 246 Jews from Yemen have been brought to Israel in the past year in small groups of twenty or so people at a time.

descriptions.value: This year so far 189 arrived with 24 coming this month. About 900 Jews remain in Sana according to the Agency, adding that their lives are not in danger. The Agency would have preferred to have kept the aliyah a secret until all the Jews had arrived. During the past month or so the ultra-orthodox haredi community have been fighting amongst themselves to prevent the newly arrived Yemenite Jews becoming too influenced by secular groups. Although the aliyah was under censorship to prevent antagonizing the Yemen government, Many cryptic references have been made in ultra-orthodox newspapers to the presence in Israel of 'new immigrants from a distressed Asian country'. One such article that was to run in a haredi newspaper a few weeks ago was stopped by the censor. The newspaper appealed to the High Court which gave the government five days to explain why they were not permitted to publish. In the meantime the censor, for some unexplained reason, lifted the ban and the story was published. Following the publication in both the haredi and popular press the Agency decided to hold a press conference to clear the air. Uri Gordon, the Jewish Agency's Chairman of Immigration and Absorption said that he regretted the lack of media discipline that undermined the importance of secrecy to ensure the safety of Jews anywhere in the world who are in danger. A few years ago the orderly secret aliyah of Jews from Ethiopia was suddenly stopped when media publicity exposed the secret flight of Ethiopian Jewry. Uri Gordon told journalist visiting the absorption centers where the new immigrants live at present, that the censor must be strong and insistent when Jewish lives are in danger. Unfortunately human nature being what it is, people do not always learn by their mistakes. Photo shows: a newly arrived immigrant brother and sister at the Rehovot Absorption Centre.

records.title: חוף הים במקום בו נבנה נמל אשדוד.

descriptions.value: Jerusalem has been turned into a white winter wonderland this winter, The snow, which normally is light and disappears almost before it hits the ground, has this year remained thick on the ground, Many thousands of visitors from all over the country have taken the opportunity to visit the capital by train to see this unusual sight, The snow, which is now melting, is expected to return in the middle of the month according to the long range weather forecast, In the meantime the flooding that occurred earlier this week has almost gone and the country's roads are open again, with few exceptions; The picture shows the view toward the Montefiori Windmill from Yemin Moshe.

Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Born 10/08/1928, Apsha, Czechoslovakia. Emigration 1946. Immigration to Palestine 1948. Interview: childhood, language situation, parental home, social surroundings. Lived in Australia. Apsha was occupied by Hungarian troops. Attended a Hungarian school. Language within the family: Yiddish. Acquired German in the concentration camp and in Bratislava. Language in school: Czech. In Czechoslovakia every Jew spoke 3 languages. Parents: very religious mother, father was a fruit trader. Religion: prayer and religious customs. Before the war she and her brother were hid by Christians, discovered and deported. Childhood memories: poverty. Relationship to her surroundings. First experiences with Anti-Semitism. Zionism: young people tended to Zionism although their surroundings rejected it. Concentration camp and rescue. Destiny of her family. After the war: she wanted to become a doctor and worked as a nurse. Return to Bratislava. Two episodes. Aliyah: problems at the border, it took a year to arrive in Israel. On board of an illegal ship. Schooling and career: 4 years of primary school, hospital. Experiences on the ship. Internation Camp in Cyprus. Arrival and beginnings in Israel: arrival to the Kibbutz, feelings and impressions. Life in the Kibbutz. Arab attack on the Kibbutz in Independence War. Episodes about father and brother. Rebuilding of the destroyed Kibbutz. Emigration to Australia and return to Israel. Longing for a real home. Emigration, return to Israel after 20#years. They purchased a house in Jerusalem. Language situation of children and grandchildren: they all speak Hebrew well. Feeling of identity and how she sees herself. She sees herself as Israeli and tries to lead an Israeli life. Active engagement in Jewish organizations. Reading: Israeli and Jewish literature. The problem of coping with the past. Identity: Israeli, Jew.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Born: 05/17/1894, Mainz. No religious parental home, did not keep Shabbat; Education: high school for girls, Studies: Medicine at the University of Freiburg (not finished) Psychologist at the U.o. Frankfurt. Emigration: 1936. Interview: Situation of communist states. Refugees and persons seeking political asylum. Swiss Army. Military service in general and in Germany. Childhood, two siblings, mother's family in Mainz, father's in Dortmund. About her mother and her love for music. Sisters' and father's death. Photography. Meeting her later husband. About an acquaintance. Writing a book. Being born in the 19th century. Times after father's death. About their deaths, medical treatment. About the time in Mainz and her two "wild" sons. F and her husband went to Frankfurt, where she worked as a psychologist at the university. Differences between children and old people. Schools. Relationship to non-Jewish surroundings. Her parents' friends. Not very religious. About an uncle's father who served under Napoleon. About relationships with non-Jews. Correspondence with the Jewish Museum of Berlin. Meyn painted her father in law and her sister in law, the paintings were sent to the Museum. Origins of the Fraenkel family. Fraenkels published the first commercial textbook. Emigration: she did not want to leave but her husband was not allowed to treat non-Jewish patients. Her husband left in December 1935 to look for a place in Palestine. Husband and son were patriots. How she feels#about this patriotism. Preparations for emigration. Beginning of a medical practice in Jerusalem. Her sons. Her husband's career. About how she learned about the events in Germany. (A maid from Berlin told her after the war). About the camps. A woman who told her about the murder of her son in a concentration camp. The members of her family died naturally. Her father in law owned one of the nicest cars in Berlin. Social contacts after the arrival to Palestine. Her husband was the only Jewish ENT specialist in the English hospital; his patients. Times of the French occupation of Mainz. About Arab patients. Language situation: her husband did not learn Hebrew, but spoke English. She speaks English and French. How she learned Hebrew. Spoke German with her husband and her maid, Hebrew with her children. About her husband: patriarch. Travels to the USA. Her husbands' illness and death.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Heinz: born 12/06/1904, Goerlitz. Education: humanistic high school, commercial apprenticeship, high school graduation, Study of law. Emigration: 1933 to Haifa with his wife. Career: 1921-25 commercial employee; 1930-33 articled clerk in a law firm; foundation of a factory for soda water with his wife; 1935 employee of the immigration organization. State Controller; retirement. Else: born 03/22/1907, Tarnowik. Secondary school, training as photographer in Berlin. Emigration: 1933 to Haifa with her husband Career: independent photographer in Berlin, foundation of soda water factory, cook, nurse. Live in an old people's home. Interview: Wedding in 1933. Zionists, went to Bali, Poland, Hungary, Triest. Capitalist certificate. 08/01/1933 arrival to Haifa. 2 room apartment with many guests. Zionist education. E: Very religious parents. Differences in the Jewish education of girls and boys. H: 100% religious home, liberal community, father extremely religious, kosher, all holidays. Became a Zionist after meeting a young doctor in 1916. Youth organization. Could not finish school because of financial difficulties. Apprenticeship in an orthodox firm in Halberstadt. He was in opposition, being a Zionist. Situation in school, graduation after end of inflation. Studied law in Freiburg and Berlin. Articled clerk. Realized that there was no future in Germany. Jews in the company in Halberstadt had to be religious. Reasons for studying law. Wanted to become a Rabbi first. Studying law#in Germany. Foundation of their own factory in Haifa, bankruptcy 1935, moved to Tel Aviv. Why they did not join a Kibbutz. About the factory which had already been organized in Germany. H: about his career. Zionist friends. 1935 H ran for elections to the municipal authority of Tel Aviv. Significance of nationality. Employed at the Hitachdut olei Germania for Zionist work, lectures. 1936-39 Arab Revolt, he went to a small village with mainly German inhabitants. 1937 move to Jerusalem. E: worked as Oseret and nurse. 1937-48 with the Hitachdut olei Germania in Jerusalem, private sessions. H: 1938-42 guardian of Else Lasker-Schueler, claims that she was not starved to death. Language Situation: German and Hebrew with one son. Language situation of their other children. One son married a Japanese woman, H does not approve. About mixed marriages. "First Jewish Japanese". Political attitudes. Zionists and Zionist movements. Present situation of Arabs. About the middle European Aliya. Problems of Immigration. Incorporation of new immigrants. German Jews - East Jews. Differences between Jews. Russian immigrants. Problems of immigrants nowadays. Arabs and settlements in Palestine. About Israel. About the soda water factory. Reasons for H's success in politics. Why they did not work in a Kibbutz (because they only spoke German). About the Kibbutz system. About different Kibbutzim. German Jews and history. Parents of H: went to the USA to his elder sister. Later to Palestine.#Transfer of money and finances. E: about the fear she felt in Germany and that she did not understand German Jews.

descriptions.value: Part A: Born Dublin, Ireland 1893 to Lithuanian immigrants. Discusses: introduction to Zionism; enlisting in British Army; appointment in British Government in Palestine; roles he filled; attempts on his life; people encountered; Herbert Samuel's work; request to join and role in Israeli Government. Part B: Involvement in, and views on, Vaad Ha'Tzirim; the Yishuv's perception of the 'Vaad'; Orthodox Jews; relationship with British Military Authority; Weizmann's role; conflicts; changes ihip; division of funnctions; activities initiated between Arabs and Jews; division of work between Jaffa and Jerusalem offices; British Jews in Administration; the 'salon of George Antonius'. Part C: Jews in Mandatory Government; British officials; Arabs; Arab officials; social interaction between the different peoples; corruption. Part D: role of Jewish officials and civilians in the sports club; the different high commissioners and their position regarding the Jewish National Home. Part E: Corruption, Arab officials; anecdotes from his work; knowledge of Jews smuggling arms into Palestine.

records.title: Absorption of Jews from Arab Countries in Israel.

descriptions.value: Born Northern Iraq, 1923. Discusses: personal biography; making Aliya via Syria, 1938; arriving in Israel; serving in British police; being drafted to IDF, 1948; story behind establishment of Moshav Azaria, 1949; serving as social leader in moshavs of new immigrants; different jobs and appointments held - particularly involving new immigrants; education; wife and children, their education; living conditions; language spoken at home; food; social environment; religion; hobbies.

records.title: Jewish Youth Movements in Czechoslovakia between the Two World Wars; Blau-Weiss Youth Movement in Austria.

descriptions.value: Father born in Bohemia, came as a child to Austria under liberal, enlightened government that accepted Jews. Around WWI Jewish 'Blau-Weiss' organization was established, influenced by similar German movements. Over years atmosphere in Austria changed, by 1933 difference between Jews and non-Jews felt. During this period Dr.Schwager joined Jewish organizations, establishing a tie for him with other Jews, planting seeds that led him to make Aliyah and join the Haganah.

records.title: סירות בחוף של הכפר א-טור בסיני.
Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Yael Ben-Mordechay spent her childhood and school years in Jerusalem. She met her husband, a kibbutznik from Ramat David, during her military service. After the marriage they first lived in his kibbutz, but then moved to Kiryat Bialik. Later they moved to Amirim, a village of vegetarians. YBM worked for a nature conservation organization for more than 20 years. Since 14 years she works as a travel guide with tourists in Israel and also with Israelis abroad (especially in Germany). She has three children and eight grandchildren.#YBM's mother came to Palestine with her husband in 1932, their house became a place to go for new immigrants after 1933. Her father was born in Koenigsberg, but spent his childhood and youth in Montreux, Switzerland. YBM only spoke German in her family, but it was forbidden to talk German outside. Her family was typically Yekkish. All of her family members learned and used their languages in different ways. Her parents had a large Yekkish circle of friends in Jerusalem. YBM grew up in an ethnically heterogeneous quarter near the university. She noticed social differences very early. She describes the distance of the Yekkes to Jews from Eastern Europe. She thinks that her growing interest in the Arab culture was a conscious setting herself apart from her family. Her parents were against her interest in the Youth movement, although her mother came to Israel as a Zionist.#YBM's grandmother on her mother's side came to Israel in the 1920s, she was a Hebrew teacher and acquainted with the intellectual elite. Her parents did not talk about the family history until their grandchildren showed interest. YBM had more information about her father and his three brothers, who all emigrated. Despite her early immigration, her mother had difficulties to assimilate in the Israeli society. She always said she never wanted to live anywhere else though. YBM talks about the difference between city life and the life in a kibbutz. She also talks about her school career and her resistance to her mother's wish to attend a technical college.#Military service brought YBM to Ramat David in 1963, she met her future husband there on the first day. Initially she felt attracted to the life in a kibbutz. She tells about their wedding and the birth of their first child. She did not want her children to grow up in the children's house, so they left the kibbutz. The relationship between her husband and her parents was rather reserved in the beginning, because his family came from Poland. In contrast she was welcomed very warmly by his parents: 'Yekke' seemed to be a good predicate to them. After leaving the kibbutz, life was very difficult for YBM and her family. She got many contacts with immigrants when she was teaching Hebrew. YBM analyzes the ideology behind the children's houses in the kibbutzim. She describes her life in the town Kiryat Bialik: she a lot of friends, the atmosphere was open-minded and spontaneous (in contrast to the Yekkish way of life in her parents' house).#YBM notices that the interests of her children's generation are more versatile than those of her own generation, which had to experience more armed conflicts. Despite the many antagonisms, YBM considers herself as Yekkish and recognizes herself when analyzing Yekkish culture and identity. She talks about her move to Amirim and her professional work. When her children went to military service she studied tourism at Haifa University. She works as a guide for tourists in Israel and for Israeli groups abroad.#Her father visited Switzerland for professional reasons in 1965, her parents then travelled to Europe several times. YBM's first stay in Berlin at the beginning of the 1990's, together with her husband, was not easy. Nowadays she has many friends in Germany through her work and has overcome the first difficulties. She considers Germany as a Western country which is very much influenced by the United States. YBM analyzes the importance to know the German language for establishing relationships in Germany. She tells about her guided tours to concentration camps in Poland and about her encounters with young Germans in Poland. She opposes the comparison of Nazi-Germany to the Israel of today. She speaks about the Second Intifada. YBM tells about guided tours on the Golan Heights and about how tourists react to the (political) reality about which they have not been correctly informed by the media. The Holocaust once was a taboo topic for Yekkes, while Jews from Eastern Europe on the contrary have always discussed their persecution. YBM tells her husband's story, whose parents emigrated in 1937 and 1939. She also tells about a visit to Poland.#YBM's her second daughter motivated her grandmother to tell her the family history on tape. YBM's children don't speak German and they are not interested in German or European passports. YBM analyzes the youth's attitude towards Israel and the growing tendency to emigration. She discusses Fanija Oz' book about Israelis in Berlin and analyzes the attitudes among the young generation towards Zionism and the idea of the Israeli State. YBM sees Israel as a country of migration and a model of cultural plurality. The new immigrants nowadays come with different motivations than the Zionists. YBM notices the increase of orthodoxy. Her grandchildren are very interested in the State of Israel. She describes the Mediterranean way of life. She also speaks about Arabic as compulsory subject and optional subject at school and makes observations on Israeli Arabs and the occupied areas. YBM also tells about a conference about Yekkes in Jerusalem and about invitations of former emigrants by German cities and the German-Israeli relationship today.

descriptions.value: The sandy place is covered with nice green grass. Photo shows: Min. of Tourism visiting a huge hothouse at Gush Katif from which beautifull vegetables are exported in winter season.

Following the ax killing of Gaza settlement member Simha Levy, settlers in the area have decided with immediate effect to stop the employment of all Arab labour. They intend to replace, in the first instance, the workforce with schoolchildren in a volunteer program. Just over a week ago Uri Megidish was murdered by two of his Arab employees while working in his hothouse near the Khan Yunis. The Gaza settlers have asked the government to allow foreign workers to come to Israel to replace in part the Arab labour. There could also be a special scheme to offer work to new immigrants who have not been able to obtain employment up until now. Already the Labour Ministry has offered to subsidize salaries of Israeli workers by just over $10 per day above the rates being paid to former Arab workers. The West Bank Karnei Shomron Local Council have also decided to fire all its Arab workers, following many terrorist killings. Photo shows: The picture shows a schoolboy volunteer working in the Jewish settlement of Gush Katif in the Gaza strip following Simha Levy's murder.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sfax, Tunisia, 1928. French education. Member and leader of Zeirim Ohavei Zion, 1945-1948. Aliya, 1948, to instruct in Hagana camps. Fifteen month service in IDF. Organizing people of Tunisian and Morrocan origin to settle in Gilat in Negev. Gilat's secretary 1951-1954, 1957. Problems of housing, agriculture, infrastructure, development and security. Social and agricultural training by veteran residents. Difficulties of agriculture as basis of economic subsistence. Parents arriving after mass immigration from Tunisia in 1949; after stay in immigrant camp in Beit Lid relocating to Jerusalem. Ten people in family; difficult conditions at first. Marrying in Tunisia in 1950 and returning to Israel. As emissary to Tunisia effecting aliya of 500 families in thirty months, 1954. Some 15,000 Tunisian Jews emigrating by 1967. Jewish community in Tunisia almost non-existent. Difficulties causing thousands to leave Israel for France in first years. Since 1954 direct absorption at settlements and abolition of transit camps. Conditions promised in Tunisia surpassed by conditions finally received. At first selection of aliya candidates by age; finally transfer of entire villages from Atlas mountains. Tunisian Jews preferring moshavim to kibbutzim.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Djerba, Tunisia, in 1924. Member of religious Zionist youth movement Ateret Tzion. Jewish Agency (JA) worker from 1947, handling immigration affairs. Immigration of Jews to France and then to Israel with Aliya Bet (illegal immigration). Help in administrative affairs from member of Tunisian government. After Tunisians independence JA still active but more discreet; immigration supposedly to France with JA paying travel expenses. Work for JA in Tunis ostensibly as JDC immigration office. Emissaries from Israel coming in 1957 with instructions not to allow old people without support to immigrate; eventually abolished but not before interviewee's parents died in Tunisia. Minimal antisemitism in Tunisia. Aliya with family in 1957. Emissary to Tunisia, 1960-1965. JA worker in Israel, 1965-1968. Founding Tunisian Kisse Rahamim yeshiva, by instruction of Rabbi Matzliah Mazuz, chief rabbi of Tunisia. Many Tunisian newcomers settling in Israel with help from various political parties and their absorption usually successful, but many have left especially intellectuals. Most Jerban Jews stayed in Israel.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-7 ביולי 2018 המתעדים את שחזור קרב קרני חיטין. בשחזור ההיסטורי של קרב קרני חיטים משתתפים כ-60-70 איש, בראשם חברי מועדון "ממלכת ירושלים", על ציודם המשוחזר בדיוק היסטורי. חלקם רכובים על סוסים, וחלקם נעים רגלית. השחזור הפך למסורת המתקיימת זאת השנה השמינית ע"י המועדון המלכד את מועדוני השחזור והסייף ההיסטורי מישראל וחו"ל. במהלך כל השנה נערכות ההכנות להכנת הציוד ולתכנון הלוגיסטי כגון מסלול המסע, מוסיקה וריקודים אותנטיים (במשתה הלילה שלפני הקרב). השחזור מושך משתתפים מארצות שונות, כולל רבים מרוסיה, שבה מתקיימים פסטיבלים דומים במשך השנה, וחברי מועדוני השחזור שלה נמצאים בקשר הדוק עם עמיתיהם בישראל.

Ultra-Orthodox Jewry in Eretz Israel during the British Mandate and Today.

descriptions.value: Claim of discrimination against ultra-Orthodox community in allotment of aliyah certificates because controlled by Zionist movement. Alternative routes to aliyah: Aliyah Bet, capitalist aliyah, yeshiva students. Founding Poalei Agudat Israel to protect these olim, most of whom became laborers. Crisis in 1927, resulting in large emigration from Eretz Israel and closing down Israel branch of Poalei Agudat Israel. Re-establishment in 1933, when many olim from Germany joined. Quarrels over ideology and distribution of resources developed and deepened between Poalei Agudat Israel, and Agudat Israel. Principal reasons for quarrels with Jerusalem wing of Aguda under leadership of Blau over issues of settlement and education. Appeal of Poalei Agudat Israel to Council of Torah Sages. Support of a small group, including Hazon Ish (Rabbi Avraham Karlitz) for Poalei Agudat Israel in area of work agreements, entry into National Employment Office, and acquisition of land from JNF for settlement.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sousse, Tunisia, 1925. Immigration to Israel. One of the founders of Moshav Gilat in the Negev. Organizing nucleus of settlers, initial inspection of site and finally settling in 1949. First living in tents while building houses. Austerity, food rationing and means of obtaining provisions in early years. Social and political crises. Ethnic composition of Gilat. Social and cultural activity; cultural gaps between different communities. Security problem; Arab terrorism. Relations with non-Jewish ethnic groups in vicinity.

records.title: The Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Describes relations between Lehi and Etzel: imprisonment of many Lehi members, 1940-42, as result of informants; executions of Pritzker and Yelenchik; organization of Lehi prisoners in jail to read books on explosives; beginning of collaboration between Etzel and Haganah, 1947, following increased Arab attacks; Lehi's position against internationalizing Jerusalem; decision to establish underground movement in Jerusalem; enlisting in Zahal after declaration of Independence.

records.title: Ha'apala (Illegal Immigration) from Italy 1945-1948 [including material from the Haganah Archive].

descriptions.value: Communication activities in Italy; the signal station at Lake Como and its capture; other signal stations; relations between refugees and the active members; the immigrant ship "Katriel Jaffe"; capture and deportation; the camps in Cyprus. UNED Joined Palmah, 1943. Wireless course. Sent to southern Italy to open wireless station. Caught, interrogated by British, released. Founded 'Miriam' wireless station in northern Italy. Communications with Palestine, Jewish Brigade and Aliya ships. Trips to Milan on vacations to meet with other Israelis. Sent as wireless operator on 'Katriel Yafe' (and 'Ha-kaf-gimel'?) ship(s). Witnessed deportation ships in Haifa and resistance on ship.

descriptions.value: "זלמן כ"ץ ז"ל נולד בשנת 1897, באוקראינה שברוסיה. עלה לארץ ישראל בעליה השנייה בשנת 1912, כשהוא בן 15 שנה. מאז ועד לשנת 1948 נטל חלק באופן רצוף בגאולת הארץ ובבניינה, בעיקר בגליל התחתון, אך עבד גם בבניית העיר תל-אביב ובשמירה במושבה רחובות. לאחר מותו מצאנו את זכרונותיו כתובים במחברת. הזכרונות לא עברו עריכה, אלא הודפסו בלשונו ובסגנונו המיוחד ... זכרונותיו מלאי תיאורים מרתקים על החיים בתקופתו, כגון: החיים בעיירה ברוסיה, חתונה יהודית ברוסיה, שיטות עבודה ועיבוד אדמה בארץ בתקופות שונות. זלמן כ"ץ היה בין ראשוני הטרקטוריסטים בגליל. עבד בהכשרת קרקעות במושבות הגליל התחתון ועד מטולה הגיע. זכרונותיו כוללים את התקופה העותומאנית, מלחמת העולם הראשונה ובנית הארץ עד מלחמת השחרור"--מן המעטפת של גרסת נייר.

descriptions.value: Born in Dresden, Germany, 1924. Refugee in England during Holocaust. Activities in Benei Akiva youth movement. Immigration by sea via Aliya Bet. Organizer of joint administration of winter detention camps in Cyprus. Main representative of immigrants vis-a-vis authorities. Lifelong desire to live on kibbutz fulfilled by settling in Kibbutz Tirat Zevi. Choice of kibbutz based on contacts with Tirat Zevi emissaries during public service abroad. Rapid integration into work, society and Hagana due to idelogical background and personal temperament. Elected to secretaryship of kibbutz during War of Independence. Active thereafter in Tirat Zevi and Hakibbutz Hadati.

records.title: Jews in the Underground in Belgium during World War II; The Rescue of Jewish Children in Belgium during World War II; The Rescue of Children from Germany, Czechoslovakia and Austria via Western Europe, 1933-1940.

descriptions.value: Attempts to rescue children from Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia through France in 1939. Studies in France. Training in pioneer training center, 1934. Immigration to Israel. Sent to France in 1939 to organize pioneer training centers for German, Austrian and Czech youths who came as refugees to France. French government willing to absorb refugees under two conditions: that the Jewish community would guarantee their material needs and that the Jewish Agency would commit they would emigrate to Israel after period of training. Committee of Jews and non-Jews headed by the Baron de Rothschild established to handle this affair. Differences as to whether more German and Czech refugees should be accepted or should they help refugees concentrated on the French border who were deported from fascist Italy. Eventually nothing was carried into effect. Leaving France to Sweden, 1939, to check possibilities of coordination of rescue and immigration operations via those countries who were not yet occupied like Russia and Lithuania. Contact with worker of Russian embassy Alexandra Kolontay. Eventually Jewish Swedish community reluctant to undertake this responsibility and only 50 refugees enjoying this arrangement.

descriptions.value: אברהם בן אליהו מוכתאר, יליד 1929, חילה שבעיראק. נולד למשפחה של ילידי המקום מדורי דורות, לאב ששימש מוכתאר הקהילה למעלה מ- 20 שנים. הפעילות הציונית החלה באוגוסט 1943, עת שהה בבצרה ונחשף לתנועה הציונית. עם שובו לחילה, התארגנה קבוצת הציונים הראשונה, שהתפתחה והגיע לכדי 60 צעירים, לה העביר את הידע שרכש. הקשר עם ציוני בגדאד נקשר באמצעות יוסף הרוקח, המשיך להתבצע ישירות והסתכם באספקת חומרים כתובים. ב- 1944 השתתף לראשונה בסמינר ציונות בבגדאד, שלידיעתו היה היחיד שנערך. אנשי הקהילה היהודית בחילה היו מודעים לפעילות, שכן זו התקיימה בבתים ובלי הסתרת החומר הכתוב. אנשי התנועה בבגדאד לא התעניינו בפעילות בחילה ולהפך. הפעילות נערכה בלי מוסדות ארגוניים, לא נגבו כספים ולא נעשו פעולות לעידוד העלייה לישראל של הקהילה כולה או אף של משפחות, אלא של הצעירים בלבד. בשנים 1945 - 1946, הוקמה מסגרת הגנה, פעילי חילה נסעו לבגדאד והתאמנו בהכנת בקבוקי מולוטוב, נרכשו 6 אקדחים שחולקו בין החברים, אם כי לא הייתה התארגנות מסודרת מעבר לאמור. המוכתאר היה מעורב בכל פעולה מול הרשויות, לרבות העלייה.

records.title: Youth Movements and Zionist Activity in Egypt.

descriptions.value: Discusses: Jewish upbringing; first encounters with Zionist movement; education; family; involvement in 'Hashomer Hatzair' in Cairo; members; figures in Zionist organization before WWII; Tzadikov; Jewish youth joining Communist activity (1937-38); conflict with Communists; WWII in Egypt; encounters with soldiers and emissaries from Israel; formation of Hashomer Hatzair, 1938-1942; location of chapter in Heliopolis and development of other chapters; people involved, 1943-44; own departure with first Aliyah group, December 1944; people in his Aliyah group; ties between Hashomer Hatzair and emissaries from Mapai's 'Kibbutz Hameuhad'; letter sent to Haim Weizmann insisting that Arab problem had to be fixed for Zionism to succeed; reasons for failure of 'Hehalutz Haachid' in Egypt; becoming distanced from Zionist Organization as representative of 'Hashomer Hatzair'; funding for Hashomer Hatzair in Egypt; number of members and chapters; their location in Alexandria, Cairo and Heliopolis; 'hachshara' at 'Havat Asher' near pyramids; Lord Moyne's assassination; legitimacy of other youth movements in Egypt; criticism of policy for sending emissaries to Egypt before establishment of State, in contrast to policy for Europe; own Aliyah via Lebanon, 1945.

records.title: Youth Movements and Zionist Activity in Egypt.

descriptions.value: Discusses: childhood and studies in Alexandria, Egypt; involvement in youth movements, including 'Maccabi'; establishing contact with Israeli soldiers, 1943; visits to Israel, 1945 and 1946; establishing youth groups run by emissaries; roles filled in 'Hechalutz'; Joe Golan's arrest, 1948; his own arrest, on accusation of spying; after arrest, working as secretary for youth movement; tense relations between Egyptian police and Zionist youth movements; reasons for staying in Egypt and not making Aliyah, 1948; own arrest, and arrest of movement leaders in response to Independence War; ideology of those arrested; arrest of Moslem rebels; conditions in El-Tur and Ag-Stap jails; release, 1949; request to leave Egypt for France, and from there to Israel; life in France - 'hachshara', political disputes; Aliyah, 1949, with group of 50 others; dispersal of his Aliyah group; involvement in Zionist group; going to Morocco for two years as emissary, 1952; return to Israel; Kibbutzim he lived in and reasons for moving; Israeli mentality; leaving Kibbutz to work for El-Al in Rishon in hopes of becoming engineer; contact with Zionist leaders.

records.title: Settlements in Israel since the Establishment of the State.

descriptions.value: Born Aleppo, Syria. Made Aliyah with group of people. Settled in Kibbutz Mesot Yitzhak in Gush Etzion. Worked in administration of fruit business. Discusses: gradual worsening of security situation; different events related to security (battles, evacuation of women and children etc.); final battle and fall of Gush; being taken prisoner; life in POW camp; release; returning to normal life; life events up until now.

Born 1920 Bialystock, Poland. Upon father's death went to live with aunt after mother remarried and moved to Israel. Discusses: Jewish education; Aliyah at age 18; studies at Mikve Yisrael; working for British Police; involvement with Lehi; leaving British Police and Lehi; marriage; livelihood; serving in tanks in IDF; fighting in War of Independence; different roles in Israeli Police; living in Yad Eliahu neighbourhood of Tel Aviv; moving with family to Jerusalem.

records.title: Daily life in the first neighbourhoods of the city of Tel- Aviv.

descriptions.value: The interviewee, Shulamit Kahana, is also known by the nickname Buba. Her maiden name was Aharonowitz. Born in Vilna in 1913. Immigrated to Eretz Yisrael in 1926, studied at the Herzliya Gymnasia, graduate of 1931 class. In the interview she talks about her school, language of instruction in German; languages spoken at home; aliya of her parents; her studies in Tel Aviv. Among the stories included in the interview are: studies in music, school hikes, family's private car, drivers' license, activities of the Hagana; sport; Tel Aviv beach, bike hike in 1928, 1931 visit to Berlin, meeting her future husband; marriage porposal, dances, cinemas in Tel Aviv. The interview took place as part of the preparations in honor of her 90th birthday.

records.title: Settlements in Israel since the Establishment of the State.

descriptions.value: Discusses: living on Tel Adashim from its founding, 1923; physical structure of Moshav; residents; importance of Hebrew language; work with children; parents' separation from families abroad; relations between people on Moshav, even with different cultural and religious backgrounds; dealing with water problems; her family's role in Moshav; education; division of roles within families; mutual responsibility; leading youth program 'Hanoar Halomed Veaoved'; social responsibility; outbreak of WWII; absorption of refugee children from Vienna, 1939.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Izmir, Turkey in 1933. Immigration to Israel with Youth Aliya, 1949. Sent for hachshara (pioneer training) in Beer Tuvia with several other girls from Turkey. Eli Mizrachi, member of Moshav Tal Shahar (future husband), sent by Moshav Movement as instructor their group. Group dispersed after one month: some girls joined parents who meanwhile immigrated to Israel; some like herself joined Moshav Tal Shahar. Marriage after two months. Relocation to Herzliya shortly thereafter.

Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Warsaw, 1934. Only child of well off Polish speaking family. Parents having social and commercial contacts with Poles. After father had been taken away and conditions in the ghetto worsened, mother deciding to relocate to Aryan side with help (for a fee) of Polish acquaintances. Being separated from his mother. Suffering a lot due to separation. Relocated from one family to another for three years until 1944. In 1944 contact was established with mother's brother, an officer in Polish Army and a bachelor who could not keep him and thus relocated him to a convent. Due to pressure converting to Christianity and becoming the priest's assistant. Difficult living conditions: scarce food supply and harsh discipline. Taken out of the convent by wife of a cousin but due to their difficult economic condition transfered to Jewish childrens' house in Bielsko, one of communist orientation. Relatives who were Zionists later relocating him to Zionist childrens' house in Gliwice. Suffering much provocation by the other children due to Christian belief which took him a long time to forget. Aliya in 1948. Settling in moshav Talmei Yafe. Never forgiving his family for not taking him in.

descriptions.value: Bar Ilan Univ. in Kiryat Onu is holding the 38th annual meeting of its board of trustees. During the course of the week several new projects will be dedicated. One of the first dedications has been the official opening of the second floor of the Institute of Advanced Torah Studies. This floor was a gift of Erica and the late Ludwig Jesselson. The Jesselson family have been generous benefactors to many Jewish causes throughout the world, including universities, yeshivot and hospitals. Ludwig Jesselson died suddenky at the beginning of April this year. Photo shows: Inside the Institute.

מראה כללי של "אשל אברהם" (בלוט א סבטה)- אלוני ממרא, מקום קדוש במערב חברון, שבמרכזו אילן עתיק, מגודר ומתוחם. התצלום נעשה באמצע שנות העשרים של המאה העשרים על ידי הצלם צדוק באסאן, בהזמנת מחלקת התעמולה של הקרן הקימת לישראל. הדפס זה הופק בשנת 1951 מן התשליל המקורי ונשלח אל אברהם יערי, על ידי הלשכה הראשית של קק"ל.

records.title: Baltic Countries Jewry between the two World Wars and during WWII.

descriptions.value: Young man in Vilna at outbreak of WWII. Attempted to join the army. Flight to Viksa in the Soviet Union. Made plans and preparations for a group that would immigrate to Eretz-Israel. Realization of plan. Going over border in Afghanistan, October 1941. Arrest in Kabul and contacts with Polish consul there. Consul sent him via India and Suez to join the Polish Army in Eretz-Israel, October 1942. Living in Kibbutz Ginnosar. Joined British Brigade. Met two sisters in Europe who were partisans in Vilna forests. At time of interview Jewish Agency worker, living in Ramat Gan.

records.title: Baltic Countries Jewry between the two World Wars and during WWII.

descriptions.value: Born in Dvinsk, Latvia. Escape of Jews to Russia, June 1941. Situation of Russian Jews and attempt to escape to Eretz-Israel. Enlistment to the Latvian Division. Service in unarmed work unit, and eventual relocation to combat unit; situation of Jews in that unit. Yiddish speaking in unit. Injury and experiences in various hospitals. Return to Latvia after his release. Meeting with the the surviving remnant. At time of interview teacher, living in Holon.

descriptions.value: Born in Bessarabia, 1903. After Russian revolution emigrating with some members of his family to Israel, 1919. The remainder emigrating to Argentina. Unification with family in Entre Rios, Argentina, 1927. Life in the agricultural Jewish colony. Return to Tel-Aviv. Return to Argentina due to family problem. Final aliyah to Israel, 1949. Pioneer in moshav Mazkeret Batya. Life as agriculturalist. Presently living in Ashdod.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen. Immigration from Yemen in 1949 through Hashed Geula camp in Aden. Attended by emissaries of Jewish Agency. Defrauded of jewelry and valuables by fellow Yemenite olim and Ashkenazi emissaries. Messianism among Yemenite Jews while immigrating. Arrival in Rosh Haayin. Newcomers' hair and side-locks forcibly cut. Yemenite Mapai repesentatives objecting to Yemenite olim joining religious parties. Daily life and absorption process in immigrant camp. Disappearance of newborn baby from children's house and unfulfilled promises of his return. Relocation to Elyashiv transitional camp, 1951-1952. Enlisting in the Israel Defense Forces. Relocation to Emek Hefer transitional settlement, 1953-1954. Struggle between Histadrut and religious parties. Activities for promotion of religious education. Losing job due to membership in Hapoel Hamizrahi. Establishment of enquiry committee to investigate disappearance of Yemenite children.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen. Immigration from Sadah, Yemen through Hashed Geula transit camp, Aden. Defrauded of jewelry and clothes. Men's hair and side-locks cut upon arrival in Israel. Arrival in Rosh Haayin. Month-old baby taken to children's house. Grandmother not permitted to visit baby. Child almost transferred from immigrant camp under pretense of requiring medical care. Removing child from children's house. Threatened with denial of food. Hearing that other children disappeared from children's house. Relocation to Elyashiv transitional camp one year later. Purchasing permanent housing.

descriptions.value: גלויה מסוג Real photo ובה תצלום שחור-לבן של בתי שכונת ימין משה מכיוון הר ציון, ממזרח למערב. בימין התצלום, ברקע, נראים מלון המלך דוד (King David Hotel), מגדל ימק"א. וקצה המגדל שמעל בנין טרה-סנטה. על הגלויה לא צויינו שם הצלם או תאריך הצילום, אך יש להניח כי דימוי זה צולם בשנות החמישים של המאה העשרים. גלויה זו לא היתה בשימוש, והיא הופקה על ידי חברת פלפוט (Palphot, Herzlia) בישראל, בשנות החמישים או בראשית שנות השישים של המאה העשרים.

descriptions.value: One of them, Atzmon, is populated by members of Garin Moran and is affiliated with Ihud Hakvutzot Vehakibbutzim. The other is Eshhar and belongs to the Kibbutz Hameuhad movement. The soldiers-farmers are living in tents, but construction has begun on permament housing. A Defence Ministry source said no land had been expropriated for the new settlements as both are on state-owned land. During the last three years, five Nahal settlements have been established in Galilee and two more will be added in coming weeks. Photo shows: the official ceremony of opening the new Nahal settlement Atzmon.#אחת מהן, עצמון, מאוכלסת על ידי גרעין מורן המשוייך לאיחוד הקבוצות והקיבוצים. השני, אשחר, שייך לתנועת הקיבוץ המאוחד. החיילים-חקלאים גרים באוהלים, אך בניית מגורי הקבע החלה. מקור במשרד הביטחון מסר שלא הופקעה אדמה ליישובים החדשים שכן שניהם ממוקמים על אדמה הנמצאת בחזקת המדינה. במהלך חמש השנים האחרונות הוקמו חמישה ייובים בגליל, ושניים נוספים יתווספו בשבועות הקרובים. בתמונה: הטקס הרשמי של חנוכת היאחזות הנח"ל החדשה, עצמון.

PM Rabin and PLO Chairman Arafat agreed on November 8, 1994 to speed up the process of Palestinian autonomy as outlined by the Declaration of Principles and the cairo Agreement. Meeting at the Erez Checkpoint at the entrance to the gaza Strip, the two leaders - in their 9th public meeting - took several steps: to hand over the administrative powers in territories outside gaza and Jericho in the fields of health and taxation; to allow more Palestinian workers to enter Israel; to allow a freer flow of Palestian goods. Education will be transferred to palestian control in September 1994. Outside the meeting, palestinain women demonstrated for the return of their sons and husbands from Israeli prisons.". Photo shows: Palestinain women demonstrating outside the Arafat-Rabin meeting - demanding release of the of their sons and husbands from Israeli prison.

סיפור עלייתה מליטא דרך כפר גלעדי ועד רמת רחל.#מ- 2:15 עד - 5:28 - ראיון ביידיש עם אשתו של משה כץ מרמת רחל על המצב ברמת רחל בתחילת שנות ה-30: עבודת נשים במטבח, אצל הנשים הגבירות בתלפיות, איך התחתנה עם בעלה, ועל השינויים אחרי מלחמת ששת הימים.#מ- 5:30 עד הסוף - ראיון ביידיש עם זהבה רוחין, עלתה לארץ מליטא ב1926. בהתחלה בתל חי, מספרת על הפילוג בגדוד העבודה בין ימין ושמאל, עברה עם קבוצה לחיפה ומשם לירושלים, לקבוצת נשים ברטיסבון. עבדה בבניין במחצבה, באוניברסיטה בהר הצופים, ובמשק בית. בהמשך ביקשו מאוסישקין לצאת מן העיר. הוא בחר מקום מחוץ לעיר, והחליט לקרוא למקום על שם "מאמע רחל" מכיוון שהיה לא רחוק מקברה. מספרת על התקופה הראשונה ברמת רחל, 1926-1927. על היחסים עם הערבים עד 1929. תושבי צור באחר הזהירו אותם לפני ה"פוגרום". עד סוף ההקלטה - תיאור מאורעות 1929.

Last week 180,000 Arabs living in areas close to the Green Line were issued with gas masks. Concern has been expressed that gas masks could be used by rioting Arabs for protection against tear gas. Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza have been trying, through the High Court, to make the army distribute gas masks to all Arabs. The army has been against such a distribution not only for the reason stated above, bud also because there is nobody who is prepared to pay for the cost of such distribution, The gas masks distributed to Israeli Jews and Arabs have been paid for by the National Insurance Institute from money paid in to a fund by citizens for the equipment. Today Jews and Arabs in rural parts of the country have started to receive gas masks. Photo shows: an Bedouin from the Israeli Arab village of Beit Zarzir collecting his gas mask. Many Bedouin from the village have served in the Israeli Army.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-29 במאי 2019 המתעדים את טקס המלידה של עדת בני-ישראל מהודו, המתקיים במערת אליהו בחיפה. טקס המלידה הוא טקס ייחודי ל"בני ישראל" - עדה שמקורה בדרום-מערב הודו (קונקאן). את הטקס נוהגים לערוך בחוג המשפחה בהזדמנויות חגיגיות (כמו לידה, בר-מצווה, נישואים, חנוכת בית). התפילה בטקס כוללת חלק המוקדש לאליהו הנביא, הנערץ על ידי בני העדה, ועל כן בישראל נוהגים בני העדה לערוך אותו גם במסגרת ציבורית במערת אליהו שעל הכרמל, לרוב אחרי ל"ג בעומר. המלידה עצמה היא קערה או מגש שעליו פיצוחים, פירות יבשים ו/או טריים ובמרכז ענף ריחן, הדס או כל צמח ריחני אחר. לא ידוע מה פירוש המילה אך מקור המנהג, כנראה, במגש תקרובת שההינדים נוהגים להגיש לאליהם במקדשים. למערת אליהו הגיעו ארבעה אוטובוסים שאספו את בני העדה ממקומות שונים בארץ, וערכו טקס נפרד, זה אחרי זה. כל משפחה הביאה מגש מלידה מכוסה במפית רקומה, הניחה אותו על שולחן או על מפה שנפרשה על הרצפה, הסירו את המפית והסתדרו מסביב. אחד הגברים הנחה את הטקס וקרא שלושה פיוטים: הראשון לאליהו הנביא, לאחריו ברכת יעקב לבניו ולבסוף קטע מתהילים. בסיום אוסף מנחה הטקס את צמחי הבושם מקערות המאלידה ומחלק אותם לנוכחים המריחים אותם יחד עם הברכה על הבשמים. אחרי כן נוטלים הנוכחים תמר מהקערות ומברכים את ברכת בורא פרי העץ, ועם תום הברכות לוקחים את קערות המלידה ומכבדים את הנוכחים. קיימים גם טקסי מלידה פרטיים שבני העדה עורכים במסגרות פרטיות ובתאריכים שונים.

Born in Czernowitz, Romania, 1922. Pioneer training in Transylvania. Leaving Bulgaria. Arrest in Cyprus. Participation in Rotenberg Seminary in Cyprus. Immigration to Israel, 1949. Brief residence in Kibbutz Sheluhot. Teaching in Pardes Hanna D immigration camp. Life in immigration camp. Methods for teaching adults (mainly from Bulgaria). Short term service as emissary of newly established Ministry of Education. Running school in Bet Arif, newcomers' settlement in abandoned Arab village. Summer school in Buber Teachers' Seminary. Teaching in Nahariya.

From old Rabbinic Iraqi family. Married 1910. Arrived Shanghai, 1913. Later grandfather, (a Rabbi, Mohel and Shohet) also came. Had 6 children in China. Lived in Japanese area. Discusses: absence of anti-Semitism; Jewish life - synagogue, religious and cultural events; donations of buildings from wealthy Iraqi families; pro-British sentiments of family; continuation of studies in English school; learning Jewish studies from grandfather; sephardic families that made fortunes during Opium Wars and had British passports and influence in British government - lived separately from other Jews, didn't participate in Zionist activity, but contributed greatly to Jewish charities and religious organizations; exception of Ezra family - that also took part in Zionist activity; division in Iraqi Jewish community between wealthy with British passports, and middle-class; rescue project for Kaipeng Jewish community, attempted synagogue restoration; success of some families in transferring businesses to Hong-Kong and obtaining influential positions in London, with rise of Communism; working as journalist for 'China-Press' from 1938, and during war; learning, from contact with Japanese and Chinese, of German pressure to establish death camps; simple and comfortable lifestyle in Shanghai; potential Shanghai had to develop before Communism arrived, 1946; growth of own interest in Zionism and Etzel; parents' and oldest brother's move to America; own Aliyah with three younger brothers.

הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שבו נראה ביתו הפרטי של חיים נחמן ביאליק ברחוב ביאליק, תל אביב, בעת בנייתו. תצלום זה נעשה בעת העבודות להשלמת הקומה הראשונה של הבית, בחודש נובמבר 1924. בראש הבית, מימין לשמאל, נראים: המפקח על הבנייה מטעם הפועלים, משה ברמן; המשורר חיים נחמן ביאליק; המפקח על הבנייה מטעם ביאליק, שמואל (סם) ברקאי. קיצוני משמאל, נראה אריה וינברג, אחד מן הפועלים שהשתתף בבנייה. על התצלום כתב ויינברג בדיו: "בשנת תרפ"ה בונים אנו בית למר ח. נ. ביאליק ברחוב ח. נ. ביאליק, תל אביב, ארצנו הקדושה". בצדו השמאלי של התצלום, מעל לבתים הנראים באופק, ציין וינברג כי זוהי "שכונת נורדיה". תצלום זה נתרם לספרייה הלאומית בשנת 1935 על ידי מר אריה ויינברג, נחלת יהודה.

הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שבו נראה חיים נחמן ביאליק (שני מימין) בחברת הפועלים העמלים על יציקת הגג של ביתו הפרטי ברחוב ביאליק, תל אביב. במרכז התצלום (חובש מגבעת ומפנה מבטו לימין) נראה המהנדס האחראי על הבנייה, שמואל (סם) ברקאי. תצלום זה צולם, ככל הנראה, ב-15 באוקטובר 1924. התצלום נתרם לספרייה הלאומית בשנת 1935 על ידי מר אריה ויינברג, שהשתתף בבנייה.

Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek has threatened to cancel the forthcoming 25th anniversary celebration of Jerusalem's reunification following the 1967 Six Day War. The mayor, always an outspoken critic of government poIicy, has threatened the cancellation of the celebration because of the situation created by Jewish settlement in the East Jerusalem village of Silwan. Kollek was concerned about the image abroad as well as the extra burden that has been put on the security forces to maintain law and order. Today thousands of Jewish left-wing peace activists joined with Arab villagers in Silwan to protest the Jewish settlers effort to take over their homes. The protest went off without incident even though there was a very small right-wing counter protest. Photo shows preparations for left wing protestors to arrive in Silwan for a demonstration against the Jewish settlers who wants to settle in Arab villages in East Jerusalem.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries (Yekkes) - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Biographical data: Maiden name: Margit Heilpern. She was born on 02/20/1923 in Vienna. She was expelled from “Gymnasium” in 1938. In December 1939, she emigrated to Palestine with Youth Aliya. First, she lived in different kibbutzim. 1942-1946 military service as nurse. Later she was employed in a home for problem children in Tel Aviv, then in a British military office. In 1946 she moved to Jerusalem, where she later got a job in a publishing house. Early retirement in 1974.#Margit Halevy's childhood and youth in Vienna: Both parents immigrated to Vienna from Galicia. They gave up their orthodox tradition. Her father was a pharmacist; he was a loyal Austrian. M.H. attended a “Gymnasium” which was mainly attended by daughters of senior officials; in her class were only a few Jewish girls. In 1938, she was expelled from the school. A friend invited her to the Zionist youth movement. Her uncle, a gynecologist who was suspected of abortions, was deported soon, but could emigrate later. M.H. thinks that the youth movement gave her age group stability after they had lost their civil rights. On a farm in Austria she finished an agricultural education as a preparation for Palestine (hachshara). Margit Halevy's first years in Palestine and her military service: She left Vienna with the last Youth Aliyah and arrived in Palestine on 12/06/1939. She was sent to kibbutz Kiryat Anavim near Jerusalem. Half a day she went to school, the other half she had to work. The adaption to the poor, simple life there was difficult for her. There was a strong bond between the Viennese group of youths and she still has friends from this period. Most members of the group moved to kibbutz Neve Eitan in Jordan Valley after two years. They wanted to found a new kibbutz there, but the climatic conditions were difficult. M.H. assumes, that another problem was the awakening of individuality, when the youngsters became adults.#In 1942, the British army demanded recruits from the kibbutzim. For Margit Halevy and a group of female friends this was a welcome opportunity to leave the kibbutz. She was sent to a hospital near Tel Aviv. She did not know English at all, but she learned it quickly during her work. The assistant nurses could take exams to get diplomas. Later, M.H. was sent to Beirut. From 1943, she served in several military hospitals in Italy; at the end she had a job in the registry of a hospital in Rome and had time to travel around Italy. In 1945, she was reunited with her parents in Switzerland. They had been deported to Theresienstadt in 1943 and were freed by a transport of the Red Cross. Later her parents moved to Australia. Her mother came to Israel after her husband's death in 1950. - M.H. was released from the army in 1946. She was then half a year employed in a home for problem children in Tel Aviv.#Later she had a job as a civilian secretary in a British military office. She moved to Jerusalem with the members of this office. Margit Halevy's language situation: In the kibbutz they had a bad Hebrew teacher. Nevertheless, she has learned Hebrew well later, she understands it perfectly though she still makes mistakes. She does not really feel at home in Hebrew literature, her favorite language for reading is English. She thinks that she (like other emigrants) does not master any language completely, even not German, because meanwhile the German language in Europe has changed. She tends to code-switching between Hebrew, English and German. English became for her as important as German, but it has not the meaning of a mother tongue. Her daughters know German from their grandmother. M.H. arranged extra lessons for the elder daughter by a teacher. The younger daughter knows German because she lives in Switzerland.#Margit Halevy's career and family (mixed remarks): About terrorism in Jerusalem during the time when the state was founded. About her husband: He was also from Vienna and a staunch Zionist, he emigrated in 1935. They married in 1947. Their living conditions were difficult during the first years. Their first daughter was born in 1949. About her husband's career in a travel agency. After her children's birth, she worked for a while as typist at home. Later she found an employment in a publishing house. (She has always preferred part-time work.) One of her most interesting assignments was an administrative job in the editors' team of the “Encyclopedia Judaica”. Since 1974, she has problems with her back, therefore she could get an early retirement. She uses her free time for example for painting classes. Towards the end of the 1980s, her husband fell ill with Alzheimer's disease, he died in 1997. The couple had travelled around a lot. - M.H. had to undergo several operations, she is glad to have recovered now. She has good relationships with her daughters and grandchildren who have interesting jobs. Her elder daughter still lives in Israel.#Margit Halevy's relationship to Austria and to the German language: She stays in Vienna periodically. Her mother used to spend her summers in Vienna. When M.H. went to Vienna for the first time after the War in 1950, she was invited by her mother. After a stroke, her mother had to lie in a nursing home in Austria and died in 1969. The Halevys often went to see their mother and some old friends from the time before their emigration. Today Margit Halevy feels like a tourist, her bad feelings towards Austria are gone. She did not have any Christian friends because most of her schoolmates were from a higher class than she was. Sometimes she was accosted verbally. Her parents tried not to attract attention as Jews. In M. Halevy ‘s opinion, antisemitism is deeply rooted in the Austrian people. In Vienna, she did not have contacts to dialect-speaking people. She was raised in standard German. The family lived in a middle-class quarter. Margit Halevy has not told her children a lot about Vienna, maybe because she was still very young when she left. She has never considered returning. Her friends in Israel are German-speaking. Most of them are former Austrians.

Ari Rath, born Arnold Rath, was born on 01/06/1925 in Vienna. Four years “Gymnasium” (grammar school) in Vienna (“Wasa-Gymnasium”). Emigration to Palestine with Youth Aliyah in 1938. 1938-1941 he stayed in the Ahava Children's Village (children's home and agricultural school), 1941-1957 in a kibbutz (Hamadya). Activity in youth movements. 1946-1948: Stay in the United States for the Zionist youth movement. 1957-1959: Studies of contemporary history and national economy in Jerusalem. 1958-1989: reporter and political journalist for the “Jerusalem Post”, since 1975 as its editor in chief. Since 1989 work as independent journalist.#Interview I: Ari Rath's youth in Vienna: The students in his “Gymnasium” were segregated into Jewish and Christian classes, nevertheless Ari Rath had contacts to Christians. Memories of a friend who was killed in World War II. Ari Rath came from a wealthy bourgeois family. His mother died early. His grandmother was very devout, she was an important attachment figure to him. His father had immigrated to Vienna from Galicia during World War I, he was a businessman. A maternal uncle emigrated to Israel in 1935. His grandmother also emigrated to Israel early. Ari Rath was not yet interested in Palestine in 1936/1937. His political consciousness and Zionist attitude did not develop until the annexation of Austria. His grandmother's influence and the antisemitic statements heard at school roused his wish to go to Palestine. He joined a Zionist youth movement. His father was arrested and brought to Dachau and Buchenwald and was released on the condition that he took his chance to emigrate to Cuba. Ari Rath's emigration and his beginning in Palestine: While their father was still in the concentration camp, Ari Rath and his brother emigrated alone to Israel. His brother got a certificate and was moved to a youth group in a kibbutz. Ari was in a preparation-camp and chosen to get one of the few certificates to an Israeli school. He departed in November 1938. For the first three years in Palestine, he lived in the Ahava Childrens' Home in Kiryat Bialik. He describes his life in the youth group and their teachers. (Ahava was a children's home with an agricultural school, founded in and transferred from Germany by Beate Berger). Despite the collective spirit, Ari attempted to maintain his individuality. After the three years, he served in the Hagana.#Ari Rath's attitude towards the German language: He and his brother decided to speak only Hebrew with each other. A.R. ranks German nowadays as his third language. In 1946, the brothers went to see their father in New York. As Ari was not yet able to speak English and they did not want to speak German, they gave their German a Yiddish “touch”, to avoid the language of the Hitler-era. Slowly, English was established as a family language with their parents.#Interview II (1999): Mixted biographical topics, statements on Ari Rath's attitude towards the German language and his political activities: Life in the Ahava Children's Home mainly consisted of physical work and school lessons. There he learned a Hebrew with a Yekkish slant. In Palestine/Israel he spoke with his brother only Hebrew, even if they hardly mastered it at the beginning, but despite their refusal of the German language in daily communication, they read German literature. A.R. thinks that nowadays the Yekkish Hebrew influences his spoken German. The teachers and educators at the children's home gave them a firm framework which helped him to overcome the hard times. He always attempted to do intellectual work besides the physical work. The education aimed at integration into the collective. In 1941, A.R. became the co-founder of a group who wanted to found a new kibbutz. He thought that life in a kibbutz was like living in a sect, therefore he tried out several groups. About the political debates in the 1940s concerning the foundation of a Jewish state. Ari Rath served in the Hagana. He got some military education already in the Ahava school and he was already very interested in politics during his first years in Palestine. Rath was involved in different groups; 1945/46 he was a member of a youth movement in Haifa. He became a leader of conferences, debates and actions. In this period, he had a negative attitude towards the British. In 1946 he moved to New York for the youth movement and met there after 8 years his father, step-mother and half-sister. His main task was giving lectures to young Jewish university graduates to encourage them to form kibbutz-groups and go to Eretz Israel.#A.R. describes his autodidactic learning of English by reading newspapers. Since the reunion with his father at the end of 1946, they intuitively spoke a mixture of German and Yiddish (though they had only spoken standard German in Vienna). Soon, they changed to English. Ari Rath analyzes his political interests. He describes the situation in Palestine in 1946/1947.#Interview III (1999): Ari Rath's activities in his early adulthood in the USA and in Palestine/Israel: About his stay in the United States in 1946/1947. Analysis of his interest for the political situation in Israel. Description of his work as a journalist. About the languages he speaks with his family in Israel and in New York. Flashback to the Ahava Children's Home. A.R. joined the Hagana in 1940 after initial skepticism. About the task to buy weapons for the Hagana in the States and to send them to Palestine. Return to Israel in September 1948. His first stay in Austria after the War was a journey from Paris to Vienna, where he had an official function for the tenth year of remembrance of the “Kristallnacht”. He returned to Israel by ship from Marseille to Haifa and arrived in October 1948. (His father would have liked his sons to help him to rebuild his business.) Back to the kibbutz he did again physical work. He considers the period in the kibbutz as very important for his life. Furthermore, he considered the commitment in the youth movements as a personal obligation. 1951-1953 he was the secretary-general of the “United Pioneer Youth Movement”. - He has always tried to maintain some private life and to keep private things in the kibbutz. Since autumn 1945, he lived in kibbutz Hamadya (first not voluntarily, because he had wanted to found a new kibbutz). Descripton of the housing conditions in the kibbutz. - In 1956, A.R. was the delegate of the Israeli Workers' Party (Avoda) at the international congress of the Socialist Youth in Finland. He considers his experiences all over the world as an important part of his life.#Ari Rath's career and his (short) marriage: 1957-1959 he stayed in Jerusalem for studies of history and economy, the kibbutz had allowed him two years off-time. He describes the entrance exams for the studies. After the engagement with an English Jewish woman in spring 1958, he searched for a job and an apartment. A friend of him arranged contacts with the publisher of the “Jerusalem Post”. Ari Rath started as a political reporter in Jerusalem. He married in November 1958. Besides his work as journalist, he continued his studies. Analysis of the problems of his marriage, his divorce. About his work for the “Jerusalem Post”. In 1960 he wrote a report on Ben-Gurion's journey to the United States and his meeting with Konrad Adenauer, which he had observed closely.#Interview IV (2000): Ari Rath's (short) military service and his career as a journalist: About his work for the “Jerusalem Post”. Once he refused the offer of an employment by another newspaper. Ben-Gurion was a very important person for him ( and a positive character). A.R. became interested in political developments already in the 1950s. He discusses the Lavon-affair and the campaign against Ben-Gurion until his resignation in 1950. About the splitting of the Israeli Workers' Party in 1956, when Ben-Gurion founded his own workers' list. The “Jerusalem Post” has always defended Ben-Gurion's line. Ari Rath describes his temporary work as Ben-Gurion's secretary: In 1965, the “Jerusalem Post” allowed him four month off- time to support Ben-Gurion in his election campaign. Rath's contacts with politicians were already formed during his period with the “United Pioneer Youth”: his experience in the youth movement enabled him a political commitment, but after this experience he made a conscious decision against a political career. In 1960, he had a stay in Washington and New York in the scope of his work as reporter. (About the separation and divorce from his wife.) After his work for Ben-Gurion, Rath became the head of staff at the editorial office of the “Jerusalem Post”. Analysis of the situation of an English newspaper in Hebrew-speaking surroundings. The “Jerusalem Post” was at this time liberal and open. Rath considers it as his own merit that the slightly strange newspaper became an original Israeli newspaper. Analysis of the political developments in the 1960s. Rath served as soldier in the Six-Day War. During the Israeli War of Independence he was in New York with the secret order to organize weapons there. About his official swearing-in to military service in New York. In Israel he later became a member of reserves. He served as infantryman in deployments in the Six-Day War#War and 1973 in the Yom Kippur War. Later voluntary military service. The years 1967-1973 were marked by his active commitment to the work as journalist and for the reserves. Before the Yom Kippur War, Rath made a journey to Santiago in order to see an uncle. Analysis of the tensions in Chile. (Rath thinks that Salvador Allende has always been a kind of model for Israel because of his socialism without communism.) He watched a revolt from the window of his hotel and was hurt by a shrapnel. He wrote critical reports from Chile, but there were problems with the censorship. Within the scope of this journey, he also went to Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro. In October 1973, he returned to Israel when the Yom Kippur War broke out. About criticism of the government of Golda Meir and Moshe Dayan and protest movements, resignation of the Meir-Dayan government at the end of 1973. A.R. thinks that then a new era in the history of Israel started. - The “Jerusalem Post” was basically faithful to the government, above all to the line of Ben-Gurion. After the Yom Kippur War, there were different political opinions among the editors. About Rath's daily work on political incidents and as head of staff.#After the war of 1973, a younger generation of politicians came to power (Rabin und Peres). Criticism of the uncompromising politics of Golda Meir. In 1972, Rath brought his father to Israel, he stayed together with him for five years: difficult years with too little private life. Rath's father died in 1977; though A.R. had not always positive feelings for him, the common time in Israel was important to him. After the editor in chief of the “Jerusalem Post” had died, there were negotiations about a successor. In 1975, Rath took over the “Jerusalem Post” together with a colleague, he became publisher and editor. Analysis of the economic situation of the newspaper during the 1980s. Disappointment about the end of these activities in 1989, when new owners forced a change of the political orientation of the newspaper, which Rath did not accept, and disappointment about the lack of loyalty among his colleagues. - Since 1990, Rath has been active at the Jerusalem Foundation and worked as a free journalist.

ISRAEL AND JORDAN OPEN THEIR BORDERS.

descriptions.value: Ever since the State of Israel's establishment in 1948, she has been in a state of war with the neighbour that shared more of Israel's border than any other country - Jordan. that state of war was ended with the Washington Declaration of 15 July 1994 and finally put into effect on the ground, 8 August 1994, in the Arava. There, Israel Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan opened the first border crossing between the two countries 6 kilometres north of Eilat, in the presence of US Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Israel Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, Jordanian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Abdel Salaam EI-Majali and a large assortment of other dignitaries. Rabin and Hassan cut a ribbon to work the opening of the border crossing - meanwhile open only to Israelis with foreign passports - with scissors handed to them by a pair of specially chosen young local Israeli and Jordanian girls. Prime Minister Rabin said in his speech: - “Friends say to us - The pace of events is too fast. We cannot keep up. Wait a moment'. Your Royal Highness, our friends in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, we have waited forty-six years. We have gone through war, pain and suffering. To prevent further loss and sorrow, we cannot wait even one day more”. Crown Prince Hassan's speech was a visionary one:; "The Aqaba-Eilat border gate represents a physical demonstration of our desire to promote inter-regional transportation networks...Our region is the birth place of civilization...In this gateway be a taken of our resolve that soon our peoples will be able to sharp, exchange and marvel at their common legacy". Photo shows The new Jordanian Tourist Office adjacent to the Arava checkpoint with Israel near Aqaba, already set up for visitors from Israel, 8 August 1994. the small complex of offices in the vicinity also houses a post office and a bank.
