descriptions.value: Front Text - 137Edit. A. Scavo#Production period - before 1935#Front Period - UNKNOWN#Category - Synagogues#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of the Magen Abraham Synagogue in Beirut. This important synagogue is situated in Wadi Abu Jamil district, the former Jewish quarter in central Beirut. It was erected around 1925, thanks to the contributions of a Sasoon family member who named the synagogue after his father. The Synagogue stills exists nowadays but it has been seriously damaged during the 1982 Lebanon war. The photograph depicts the interior of the Synagogue which looks like a church's structure: a large prayer hall flanked by two arched corridors faced the central holy arch, called Hekhal (a generally ornamental closet which contains the Torah scrolls; located in most case in the direction of Jerusalem). The Hekhal is closed by a Parohet (curtain) and on its top hang the Tablets of Law (two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments). Opposite to it appears#Stamp Place on postcard - top right corner of back#Stamp Origin - Lebanon (Republic)#Stamp Period - c. 1935#Post office marks Origin - Lebanon (Country), Marjayoun (City)#Post office marks Languages Of Text - French

records.title: HERMON SLOPES OPEN FOR SKI SEASON.

descriptions.value: Usually by this time of the year the Mount Hermon ski slopes would have been open since December last year. However, like many ski resorts in Europe, the type and quantity of snow needed to enable the ski slopes to open was very late in coming. In fact only last week did the first skiers of the season.come to the Hermon. The north of Israel has had below average rainfall this winter which has meant that the Kinneret is still 3 meters below the level it should be for this time of the year. The past week has seen a general improvement in the north, when several stormy days brought heavy rain and snow to the region. The national water authority, Merkorot, had been issuing warnings that there will be a shortage of water for agriculture if there is not a dramatic improvement in the water reserves. Heavy snow on the Hermon is a welcome for the skiers and the water authority because nearly all the snow which is on the Hermon at the moment will, by the summer, find itself in the Kinneret Lake making up the important shortfall of fresh water. The Hermon facility has four ski runs of varying difficulty. The total distance of all the runs together is twelve kilometers. Photo shows: The picture shows a skier on the last section of the ski slope on Mount Hermon.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-14 ביוני 2020 המתעדים את המיסה שעורכים הכרמליטים במערת אליהו. את המיסה ערכו נזירים כרמליטים ממנזר סטלה מאריס שעל הכרמל במערת אליהו, שיש בה ארון קודש והיא מתפקדת כבית כנסת. היו שם ארבעה נזירים, נזירה אחת וכחצי תריסר נוצרים מחיפה. אבל מיסה קתולית בבית כנסת יהודי(!) עד 1948 מערת אליהו הייתה מאוכלסת בסופים-מוסלמים שהתירו ליהודים, נוצרים ודרוזים, שהמקום קדוש גם להם, להתפלל בה. כיום, המערה שייכת ליהודים בלבד, אף שבשלט שמעל לכניסה למערה הפנימית כתוב: "כִּי בֵיתִי בֵּית תְּפִלָּה יִקָּרֵא לְכָל הָעַמִּים" (ישעיהו נ"ו, 7).הודות לתקנת סטאטוס-קוו מותר לכרמליטים לערוך בה מיסה פעם בשנה, ב-14 ליוני. אף אחד לא הפריע לטקס, שנמשך כשעה. דוגמה לסובלנות. לדנצ'ו ארנון רק בעיה אחת: האם לחבוש כיפה כיהודי בבית כנסת או להיות גלוי-ראש כדרך הנוצרים.

History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Discusses: working for K.K.L, as of 1945; how he came to work there; positions he filled; majority of work did in Haifa area; city planning; land division; procedure behind selling land; property William Clark transferred to K.K.L. in Haifa, 1953-4; memories from British Mandate; treatment of property of missing persons; work done by K.K.L. offices in Emek Zvulun; appointment as land representative for northern property; issues under his jurisdiction; power of labour; contractors; ties between preparing land and settlement division; work done straightening land for agriculture and settlement (1967); use of dynamite.

records.title: History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Discusses: own Aliyah, 1949; integration; working in agriculture for Keren Kayemet, near Beit Zayit; teaching forestry to new immigrants; education and knowledge received from working in afforestation for 40 years; problems with afforestation; deciding on plots for forests; overview of agricultural projects for Beit Zayit residents, 1950's; income in Keren Kayemet; pruning problem and mechanical solution found; nurseries and seeds; variations in forest; crowding of saplings; outcome of forest; money Keren Kayemet made from selling trees; use of trees for plots; makeup of trees; disinfecting; cooperation with other Mediterranean countries, especially regarding forest fires; different types of plants grown in nurseries; use of seeds gathered; nurseries' specialization in species appropriate to different locations; how to minimize damage from forest fires; dealing with difficulty of putting out fires; cooperation with various sources; contribution of Keren Kayemet to Israeli outdoors by planting forests and creating parks. Emphasizes the need to document the role of Keren Kayemet personnel in afforestation in Israel.

records.title: History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Developed interest in forestry and forestization, 1943-46. Received PhD, 1949. Aliyah, 1949. Worked in research. Discusses: forestization in Israel; collaboration with Prof. De Filipis; field workers and their professionalism; administrative work; Amiud Gur's promotion under British; relations with Ministry of Agriculture following creation of State of Israel; publishing reports; his work in Israel; relations with researchers abroad; Israel's work in forestry as compared to other locations in Mediterranean; stories about eucalyptus and poplar trees; industrial use of trees in Israel; number of saplings for planting; planting on sides of streets.

Apprenticed with shoemaker in Zakho. Engaged in sending rafts of wood to Mosul, then opened a store in Christian village, returning every Shabbat to Zaco. Jews of Zaco, young and old, devotedly prayed every day. At age 17 he left Zaco.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Immigration from Yugoslavia. Life in immigrant camp. Induction into the army. Establishment of moshav Beit Nekofa, 1949. First months. Relations with the Jewish Agency. Lands and property distribution in moshav. Moroccan settlers in Beit Nekofa, 1953. The State of Israel as place of refuge.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Irit Ovadia grew up and attended high school in Jerusalem. After serving in the military she studied English and worked as a teacher in Be'er Sheva. In 1984 she became the manager of the local conservatory and organized students' exchanges. She is married and has 3 children.#IO's parents immigrated in 1939, her father studied and her mother worked as a nurse. Later her father fought in the War of Independence, in those years, IO's grandparents took care of her. IO's brother was killed in the Yom Kippur War in 1973.#IO is afraid she will make many grammatical mistakes when speaking German in the current interview, and thinks she will probably switch to English often. She has never learned German systematically. She thinks it was unusual in her generation that Yekkish parents spoke German with their children. Some of their friends were therefore angry with IO's mother. Her cousins don't know German at all. Today German is useful for IO's profession.#After she finished her military service, IO went to Paderborn together with the first German-Israeli student's group after an invitation by the Foreign Office because she spoke German. Not all of the members were Yekkish. After IO came back from this trip, she went to the US for 8 months. On her return to Israel she started to study at Be'er Sheva university and met her future husband, a sports teacher. IO's parents had nothing to object, i.e. with respect to his background; her parents in law came from Iraq and all of her husband's siblings are university graduates. IO became an English teacher at the new university of Be'er Sheva. After two years in Be'er Sheva, IO and her husband took their private residence in Omer. Some years ago her parents also moved from Jerusalem to Omer.#IO went to Germany for the first time when she was 15 years old in order to see some aunts in Dortmund. Her parents had gone there before. Before their journey her parents hardly ever spoke about Germany, her grandparents sometimes wanted to return. IO tells an episode how her father went pale from fright, when they were queuing in a post office in Cologne, and he all of a sudden recognized the horrible loud voice of a KZ-official from Buchenwald. Only then she understood what it meant to her father to be back in Germany., she had never asked him before. IO and AB discuss the fear of asking questions or telling about the past.#IO describes how she has slowly noticed the differences between Yekkish, East European and oriental culture in Israel. Her parents did not appreciate Yekkish virtues more than those of others. Even though they lived in Yekkish Rehavia, they sent IO and her brother to high schools with children from various ethnic backgrounds. IO describes the strict rules in other Yekkish homes, her parents were more “relaxed”. Her grandparents hardly knew Hebrew, her parents learned it well but still prefer to read German books. IO does not have negative feelings towards one of the languages. She tells about her father's professional career in Israel as professor and head of the Israeli State Archives.#IO's personal contacts in Germany and her knowledge of the language became useful during her work at the conservatory: she organized a students' exchange program. IO always takes the Israeli students to concentration camps when they visit Germany. She describes their discussions about coming to terms with the Holocaust. IO's parents did not have negative feelings towards young students from Germany. IO has never given up her personal contacts in Germany, she thinks that a general interest for interpersonal relationships is another reason for official international partnerships. IO's conservatory has partnerships with Wuppertal and Rosenheim, and furthermore IO has contacts with France and Belgium. IO is especially interested to organize common visits of young Germans and Israelis to concentration camps, she considers it as important for both sides. She would be interested to visit Buchenwald because her father was a prisoner there, but she is afraid to go. She has been to the 60-years-commemoration-ceremony of the “Kristallnacht” in Dachau. She felt proud of being there as an Israeli and she could understand the feelings of her students coming there with the Israeli flag. IO tells that staying in Wuppertal, the hometown of her father, is always exciting for her, her heart is pounding. Nevertheless she loves to be there with her parents. Staying in Bavaria is different, she remains a stranger though she has good friends. The mentality of the people is not familiar to her. IO thinks that her mentality is more similar to the mentality in North-West-Germany, because her family came from there and some of her relatives live there.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Yael Rosenberg was born in Jerusalem and spent her school years there. After finishing high school she studied fashion at the university in Tel Aviv. Only afterwards, when she was 22 years old, she started her military service. There she met her husband, they married in 1977 and have three daughters. For 15 years she worked in the fashion sector, in 1989 she started working in a rape-crisis-center in Jerusalem.#YR's parents spoke German with each other, she still speaks German with her father. Her husband has Polish roots. Her father and his brother were sent to England with a Kindertransport. By that time her grandfather was in Dachau. Her grandparents escaped via Cyprus and Rhodos, YR's father helped them to get visa for British Mandate Palestine but then lost contact with his parents. A few years later YR's father found out her grandfather lived in New York, after re-establishing contact her grandfather immigrated to Israel too in 1949. The brother of her grandfather also immigrated from England a few years later. YR's father first was not religious like his father, but became a believer after his father's death.#YR's parents and grandparents did not tell anything about their past even though she asked. Only when YR's elder daughter dared to ask some questions, her father started to tell. When she was young, her grandmother encouraged her parents to let her visit Germany with a youth delegation. She visited Munich, where her grandmother came from, and met the mayor Hans-Jochen Vogel. She came back with a German friend, who had accompanied the youth delegation, and it shocked her parents. YR only went to Vienna for the first time five years ago, her father did not want to tell her where he lived. YR felt home immediately in Germany, because it was something special that she knew the language of the country perfectly. The only bad feelings came when visiting Dachau, where parts of her grandmother's family were imprisoned and killed. When she came to Austria for the first time she had more inhibitions, especially when she heard the Viennese dialect, the language of her grandparents, which gave her bad feelings.#There was a lot of hatred in her father's family against Austria and the Austrian culture and language. But when his grandchildren began to ask him about his past, he also started to put down his personal memories for archives. The historian Albert Lichtblau from Salzburg encouraged Friedlaender to write down his experiences in German, planning to make a book of it. When she read his notes, she detected a father who was completely different from the one whom she had got to know. She is now very interested to preserve all his memories and to pass it to the next generations of her family.#In Jerusalem the Friedlaenders lived in Rehavia, by then a very Yekkish quarter. However YR always thought she was the only child who spoke German at home. She quickly began to speak Hebrew when she came to the kindergarten and her brother, who is ten years younger, always spoke Hebrew with her. She was proud of knowing two languages, later she also estimated the cultural knowledge passed to her with the language. YR's parents did not appreciate her friends from non-European families; there were several conflicts during her teenage-years. In university YR met people from various ethnic backgrounds. Her parents were typical Yekkes: strict, accurate, disciplined etc.. Her parents educated their children very strict and she hated it as a young girl. Her grandmother was warmer, she was YR's best friend. YR thinks that maintaining different cultural traditions is very important for the Israeli society. Her parents had many prejudices towards her husband, whose family came from Eastern Europe.#YR's husband is working for a news agency which provides most of the information on Israel for news agencies worldwide. He knows many German correspondents and understands German. YR's children don't know German. YR sometimes arranges youth exchange programs between Mevaseret, where she lives, and their German twin town Sankt Augustin. Her daughter has been to Austria once; her children are more interested in Europe than in North America. According to YR many difficulties of the Israeli society result from the new immigration waves. She thinks most of the groups will assimilate within a few decades, but that the Israeli society should also accept differences. She is not worried about young Israelis or new emigrants, who leave the country, because she considers it normal. With the beginning of the Second Intifada, some Palestine colleagues left the rape-crisis-center, though she considers their hotline for Arab women as especially important. She thinks both parts, the Jewish and the Palestinian one, are under enormous pressure from outside. Because of her husband's profession, YR's family always has to be very neutral: they don't have political discussions when they have foreigners at home.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Orit Zaslavsky's parents lived in kibbutz Hulata until she was two years old, then they moved to Jerusalem. Her parents divorced when she was eight years old. OZ then lived with her mother in New York for one year, afterwards she lived with her father in Israel. After having finished high school she served two years in the military. She studied Mathematics in Jerusalem and moved to Haifa in 1972. She got married and continued her studies, of which two years in the US. She got a doctorate from the Technion in Haifa in 1987. Later she also did a post-doctorate at the university of Pittsburgh. She is a professor of Mathematics Education at the Technion Haifa.#OZ's father and her uncle Ari came to Israel without their parents with the Youth Aliyah. Her grandfather at that time was in Dachau, when he was released he emigrated to the US. Her father had a hard time getting used to the kibbutz. OZ's parents got to know each other when her father went to see her grandfather in the US after the war. Her parents left the kibbutz when she was 2 years old and they divorced when she was 8. After a year with her mother in New York she moved to her father in Jerusalem. When OZ was 10 years old, both of her parents had married again and she stayed mainly with her father. She grew up in Rehavia, the most Yekkish quarter of Jerusalem. Her father, who became a lawyer, was very dominant in her life. OZ always had a close relationship to her father's brother Ari Rath. Rath worked as a journalist and later editor of the “Jerusalem Post”, OZ often visited him after school.#OZ describes the difference between the two brothers: they did not always get along well, though they usually were proud of each other. Her uncle expected a lot from her, she sometimes felt pressurized by him. Political knowledge was very important to him. Nowadays he still often stays with her for the holidays. He took her children to Vienna to show them their roots. OZ decided to learn Latin because of her father's and her uncle's influence, who had to leave their grammar school with ancient languages before they could finish it. OZ former husband, the father of her 3 children, was an engineer. She now has a new partner, from Bukovina. OZ first wanted to study law, but then decided not to follow in her father's footsteps. Her father wants his grandchildren to achieve academic degrees, but OZ does not consider this an absolutely necessity. Her eldest son gave up his studies and is now producing movies. One of OZ's children criticized her that she does not motivate them to study. Her daughter and her first son had a good relationship to OZ's mother. Her children have a rather difficult relationship with their grandfather. Her second son has a good relationship with her uncle Ari.#OZ's parents spoke English with each other and sometimes Yiddish, but never German. OZ spoke English with her mother. She did not want to learn German, there was a time she could not stand the language. When she finally came to Germany and Austria her opinion changed. OZ has got many Yekkish acquaintances. She describes the difference between her mother and her father. Her maternal grandparents came from Eastern Europe, OZ and her parents went to see them several times. One aunt, his father's half-sister, grew up in America and behaved more American. Later this aunt immigrated to Israel. OZ's father and her uncle are not typical Yekkes either in OZ's opinion: they are untidy, unpunctual and very lively.#OZ came to Vienna for the first time with her father and her uncle. She had been to Austria before, but didn't want to go to Vienna. Her father and her uncle don't have negative feelings towards the city. Her father goes to Germany often, he worked for the embassy in Bonn. OZ describes her attitude towards Austrians and Germans; she thinks she can trust her uncle's friends in Europe.#OZ thinks that there are big differences between the generations and their culture. Some Israeli traditions are still popular among all generations. OZ describes problems with her Arab students in Haifa, who sometimes do not accept their training methods. Also there are demonstrations on campus often and there is always some fear in her mind.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון בתאריך 26 לדצמבר 2015, במהלך אירועי חג המולד בפסוטה ומעיליא, שני כפרים מלכיטים (יוונים-קתולים) בגליל. לפסוטה יש מסורת של חגיגות עממיות לכבוד חג המולד, שלושה ימים של שמחה עם בזאר של חג, מופעים, תהלוכות, אמני רחוב, אוכל ושתיה. בני כל הדתות מוזמנים לחגוג עם בני פסוטה. את הבאים לחגיגות מקבלים צעירי הכפר בסוכריות ובריקודים. עץ חג המולד הענק ניצב בחצר הכנסייה, עם מאות נורות צבעוניות ותאורה מתחלפת. גם בתי הכפר וסמטאותיו מקושטים בתאורה צבעונית לכבוד החג. מתקיימת תהלוכה של להקת דבקה דרוזית.בכנסייה המקושטת שוכב בסלסילה "ישוע התינוק" (רפליקה של הבּוּבּה שמככבת בטקס הקתולי של חג המולד בבית לחם. על פי המנהג העממי-כפרי נבטים מסמלים את הלידה וההתחדשות. ליד ה"אבוס" (Manger) מתקיים שחזור מערת הלידה.

descriptions.value: Born Damascus,1896. Memories about the Kitab, the Jajam and as tailor apprentice. Fled to Beirut escaping the army. Called by a brother, arrival in Vera Cruz in 1912. Discusses itinerary to Mexico City. Memories about neighborhood la Merced and Jajam Dabbah. Worked with non Jews on trust. Memories about Isaac Capon and Mount Sinai, and private ceremonies. Worked as salesman on commission. Commercial bonds with Pancho Villa. Discusses labour occupation in textile factories under Cardenas' ruling. Father and son participated in hotel industry.

Born Mexico in 1913. Family memories from Damascus and immigration. Discusses incidents in La Lagunilla, with Camisas Doradas (Golden Shirts). Attended a nun's school. Active in Comite de Madres de Monte Sinai (Mount Sinai Mothers' Committee) since 1960, served as chairwoman. Discusses the Union Femenina (Women's Union) since 1938. Refers issues as help to newly married, to Damasquins, and financial sources. Discusses women relationship with Keren Hayesod, Monte Sinai, Tzedaka Hu Marpeh, Comite Israelita de Mexico (Israelite Committee of Mexico) and Cruz Roja (Red Cross). Discusses splitting of the community from Aleppo, Monte Sinai, 1938 and help to the State of Israel.

Born Jerusalem in 1924. Family memories of Palestine. Immigrated to Mexico in 1925. Lived in Parral de Chihuahua. Worked in the industrial area. Discusses relationship with Unions. Founded Sephardic Zionist Youth, 1947 in Mexico. President of the Sephardic Zionist Youth Federation. Presided over the Patronato del Colegio Sefaradi, 1954-1955. Discusses Hebrew teaching, scholarships and relationships with teachers and shlichim. President of the Sephardic Union, referred to Aracha, donations. Relationships with Tiferet Tzion Youth. Discusses endogamy and mixed marriages. Relationships with FESELA and among communities. President of Sephardic area in Keren Hayesod. Participated in Mexican Jewish delegation for boycott against Mexico. Discusses reactions of Central Committee when turmoil in Gaza, Samaria and Judea.

records.title: History of the Jewish Police (Jewish Division of the Mandatory Police).

descriptions.value: Born in Jerusalem, 1919. Member of Hagana. Service in Jewish Division of Mandatory police, 1938-1944. Noter (guardsman) in Hartuv, Atarot and Jerusalem, 1938-1939. Training instructor for the police in Jerusalem Kishle, 1940-1944. Service in Israeli police, 1948-1972. Work in Tel Aviv security unit accompanying David Ben-Gurion. Investigations officer in detectives section. Activities in Sheikh Jarrah (Jerusalem) during Six Day War. Retired as chief inspector.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: 1st Interview: An earlier interview that, with some variation, deals with the same issues as the one from February 1975.#2nd Interview: Assigned as Jewish Chaplain for the 8th Corps Headquarters of 3rd Army. Entered Germany Pesach, 1945. Discusses: life in Buchenwald following liberation (holding Sabbath services; trying to contact family of survivors); how the Holocaust shaped survivors' Jewishness; 'Kibbutz Buchenwald' and Zionist survivors who wanted to go to Palestine; distribution of 500 Swiss visas to survivors; Jews who fled once Russian rule came into effect; establishment of D.P. camps; dealing with illegal goods; relations with Rabbi Robert Marcus and Rabbi Zemach; role, and criticism of, JDC.
